description.summary: Legendary horse-like creature with single spiral horn on forehead, symbol of purity and grace throughout medieval Europe and beyond.
description.full: The unicorn is a legendary creature depicted as a white horse with a single, large, pointed, spiraling horn projecting from its forehead. Associated with purity, grace, and healing powers in medieval European tradition, the unicorn could allegedly only be captured by a virgin. Historical descriptions likely arose from misidentified accounts of rhinoceros or oryx, combined with narwhal tusks sold as 'unicorn horns' in medieval Europe. The unicorn became a powerful Christian symbol and appears prominently in heraldry, including as Scotland's national animal.

physical.appearance: White horse with single spiral horn, goat-like beard, cloven hooves, lion's tail

features.description: Single long, pointed spiral horn projecting from forehead
Split hooves like goat or deer rather than horse

physical.morphology: Horse-like body combining features of multiple animals: horse body, goat hooves and beard, lion's tail, deer-like grace

abilities.description: Horn (alicorn) believed to purify water and cure poison
Could only be captured by a virgin maiden

range.description: Mythological accounts primarily from medieval Europe, with earliest descriptions from ancient Greek natural histories

first_recorded.source: Ctesias' Indica describing one-horned wild ass

peak_activity_periods.description: Height of unicorn symbolism in European culture and heraldry

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Greek natural histories, likely based on travelers' accounts of rhinoceros, oryx, or other animals. Narwhal tusks imported to Europe were sold as unicorn horns.
origins.earliest_accounts: Ctesias of Cnidus (circa 400 BCE) described one-horned wild asses in India
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to medieval bestiaries, Christian symbolism, heraldry traditions

timeline.significance: First Western written account of unicorn-like creature
Unicorn becomes symbol of Christ, purity, and the Virgin Mary
Narwhal tusks sold as unicorn horns for enormous sums, used medicinally
Unicorn becomes supporter of Scottish Royal Arms, later UK Royal Arms

history.modern_era: The unicorn remains a powerful cultural symbol, appearing in literature, fantasy media, and as Scotland's national animal. No serious cryptozoological investigation.

physical.name: Alicorns
physical.description: Numerous 'unicorn horns' in medieval collections, now known to be narwhal tusks
physical.analysis: All examined specimens are narwhal tusks

historical.name: Ancient accounts
historical.description: Greek and Roman natural histories describing one-horned creatures
historical.analysis: Likely based on rhinoceros, oryx sightings from distance, or combined animal reports

mythological.name: Symbolic creature
mythological.description: Unicorn as purely symbolic Christian and medieval allegory

historical_basis.name: Rhinoceros misidentification
historical_basis.description: Travelers' accounts of rhinoceros distorted through retelling

historical_basis.name: Oryx conflation
historical_basis.description: Arabian oryx viewed from side appears single-horned

historical_basis.name: Narwhal tusk trade
historical_basis.description: Viking narwhal tusk trade reinforced unicorn belief in medieval Europe

stories: The Lady and the Unicorn tapestries
folklore.beliefs: Symbol of purity, grace, healing. Only capturable by virgin maiden. Horn purifies water and cures poison.

symbolism.purity: Most enduring association, especially female chastity
symbolism.christ: Medieval Christian symbol for Christ and resurrection
symbolism.scotland: National animal of Scotland, appears on Royal Arms
symbolism.healing: Alicorn believed to have medicinal properties
